contextId.information: Rocks never change and become soft, and these people never change and become sorry when they do evil things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: hard hearts

contextId.information: These words describe the people of Israel who will not treat Ezekiel kindly when he tells them what God says. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: briers and thorns and ... scorpions

contextId.information: This phrase suggests that the people resist God and are unwilling to obey him. The heart is used to describe the place in the body where a person decides what they want to do. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:02:04|2:4]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: hard hearted

contextId.information: Ezekiel speaks of being sad and tired because Yahweh had commanded him to do things he did not want to do as if Yahweh were pushing him down into the ground. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: for the hand of Yahweh was powerfully pressing on me

contextId.information: Bonds are ropes or chains that keep a person from moving. It is not clear whether the word "bonds" is a metaphor for something Yahweh does that is as if he had bound Ezekiel (UDB) or if he used literal, physical ropes. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am placing bonds on you

contextId.information: The supply is called a staff because some people need a staff to walk and do their work, and people need bread to live. Bread represents all kinds of food. AT: "the supply of food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the staff of bread

contextId.information: "from there a fire will spread out and burn up all the people of Israel." Yahweh speaks of how he will punish Israel as if he were going to set fire to a house and of the people of Israel as if they were the family that lives in that house but were at that time outside the house. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: from there a fire will go out to all the house of Israel

contextId.information: Walking is a metaphor for the way a person lives. AT: "have not lived according to my statutes" or "have not obeyed my statutes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: have not walked in my statutes

contextId.information: A "staff" was something that people leaned upon to support them. This phrase is a metaphor for means removing the supply of food that the people were depending upon. See how "staff of bread" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:04:16|4:16]]. AT: "cut off your food supply" (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: break your staff of bread

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the Israelites as if they were a married woman who looks at other men and desires to sleep with them. AT: "and by the way they desired strongly to worship idols" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and by their eyes that whored after their idols

contextId.information: Yahweh uses the terms "pour out" and "fill up" to compare his acting in anger with pouring out water and filling a jar. Together they emphasize that Yahweh will punish the people severely. AT: "I will punish you severely because I am very angry." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: I will pour out my fury against you and fill up my wrath upon you

contextId.information: Terror is spoken of as if it were clothing. AT: "everyone will see how terrified they are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and terror will cover them

contextId.information: The city is spoken of as if it were a container, and perversion is spoken of as if it were something that could fill that container. The abstract noun "perversions" can be written as a verb. AT: "all the people in the city do wicked things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: the city full of perversions

contextId.information: The people speak of themselves as if they were good cuts of meat and of the city as if it were a pot in which the meat was stored or cooked. The metaphor suggests that they are important and safe within the city. AT: "This city is like a pot that will protect us as a pot protects meat." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: this city is the pot, and we are the meat

contextId.information: Ezekiel speaks of the Spirit of Yahweh inspiring and empowering him to prophesy as if the Spirit of Yahweh fell upon him. AT: "the Spirit of Yahweh empowered me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the Spirit of Yahweh fell on me

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the people whom they have killed as if they were good cuts of meat and of the city as if it were a pot in which the meat was stored or cooked. See how you translated this metaphor in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:11:02|11:3]]. AT: "The people you have killed ... are like the meat in the pot, and this city is the pot. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The people you have killed ... are the meat, and this city is the pot

contextId.information: The people had spoken of themselves as if they were good cuts of meat and of the city as if it were a pot in which the meat was stored or cooked. Yahweh says that this in not true. See how you translated this metaphor in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:11:02|11:3]]. AT: "This city is not like a pot that will protect you as a pot protects meat." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: This city will not be your cooking pot, nor will you be the meat

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of obeying his statutes as if it were walking in them, like person would walk along a road. AT: "the one whose statutes you have not obeyed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the one whose statutes you have not walked in

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of dwelling among the people who are in exile as if he were a sanctuary for them. AT: "I have been with them" or "I have been like their place of worship" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have been a sanctuary for them

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of all of the Israelites who are in exile as if they are one person, with one heart and one spirit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will give them one heart ... give them a heart of flesh

contextId.information: Here the word "spirit" represents the thoughts and disposition. Yahweh speaks of causing the people to think new thoughts as if he were giving them a new spirit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will put a new spirit within them

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the people being stubborn as if they had a stone heart and of their being willingly obedient as if they had a heart of flesh. He speaks of causing them to become willingly obedient as if he were exchanging those two hearts. AT: "I will cause them to stop being stubborn and instead cause them to obey me willingly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will take out the heart of stone from their flesh and give them a heart of flesh

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of obeying his statutes as if it were walking in them, like person would walk along a road. AT: "they obey my statutes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they will walk in my statutes

contextId.information: Ezekiel speaks of the vision ending as if the vision was an object that had been upon him and then left him. AT: "the vision that I had seen ended" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the vision that I had seen went up from upon me

contextId.information: People being able to understand Yahweh's message and what he is doing is spoken of as if the people were able physically to see. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Perhaps they will begin to see

contextId.information: Here the word "sign" refers to something that communicates a special warning to those who see it. Yahweh speaks of Ezekiel and his actions as being this warning. AT: "have made you to be a warning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: have set you as a sign

contextId.information: Here the word "sign" refers to something that communicates a special warning to those who see it. Ezekiel speaks of himself and his actions as being this warning. AT: "I am a warning to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am a sign to you

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of enabling the Chaldeans to capture the prince as if he himself were catching the prince in a trap that he had set. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will spread out my net over him and he will be caught in my snare

contextId.information: The phrase "in the middle of it all" refers to the stones of the wall that Yahweh will break down. He speaks of destroying the people in his judgment as if the wall would crush them to death when he breaks it down. AT: "and all of its stones will crush you to death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you will be annihilated in the middle of it all

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of these women using beauty, mystery, and lies to deceive people as if the people were animals that the women hunted down and trapped with their charms. This can be stated in active form. AT: "that they use to hunt down people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: used to hunt down people

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the elders committing themselves to worshiping idols as if the elders had "taken their idols into their hearts." AT: "have devoted themselves to idols" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: have taken their idols into their hearts

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the idols that the elders worship as if they were blocks over which the elders stumble, and of being determined to worship those idols as if they had placed those stumbling blocks in front of their faces. AT: "have resolutely determined to worship the things that lead to iniquity" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: have put the stumbling block of their iniquity before their own faces

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the idols that people worship as if they were blocks over which the people stumble, and of being determined to worship those idols as if they had placed those stumbling blocks in front of their faces. See how you translated this metaphor in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:14:01|14:3]]. AT: "who resolutely determines to worship the things that lead to iniquity" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who puts the stumbling block of his iniquity before his face

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the idols that people worship as if they were blocks over which the people stumble, and of being determined to worship those idols as if they had placed those stumbling blocks in front of their faces. See how you translated this metaphor in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:14:01|14:3]]. AT: "who resolutely determines to worship the things that lead to iniquity" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and puts the stumbling block of his iniquity before his own face

contextId.information: Here the word "sign" refers to something that communicates a special warning to those who see it. The word proverb refers to what people will say about that sign when they see it. AT: "I will make that man to be a warning and a proverb" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: make him a sign and a proverb

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the people no longer worshiping him as if they were to wander away from him and no longer follow him. AT: "will no longer stop worshiping me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will no longer wander away from following me

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the supply of bread as if it were a staff. The word "bread" represents all kinds of food. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:04:16|4:16]]. AT: "end the supply of its food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: break the staff of its bread

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of killing people and animals as if it were cutting them off, like a person would cut a branch from a tree. AT: "kill both man and beast in the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: cut off both man and beast from it

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of expressing his fury as if his fury were a liquid that he pours out from a container. AT: "I will express my fury" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: pour out my fury

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of killing people and animals as if it were cutting them off, like a person would cut a branch from a tree. The word "her" refers to Jerusalem. AT: "to kill both man and beast in Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to cut off both man and beast from her

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of fire burning things as if the fire consumed them. AT: "the fire will destroy them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the fire will consume them

contextId.information: The Amorites and Hittites were both pagan people groups who lived in the land before the people of Israel conquered it. Yahweh speaks of Jerusalem's father and mother belonging to these people groups to express that she was born into idolatry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: your father was an Amorite, and your mother was a Hittite

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of Jerusalem as if it were an unfaithful wife who sleeps with other men in exchange for payment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: acted like a prostitute

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of Jerusalem's immoral actions as if they were liquids and of committing those actions repeatedly as if it were pouring those liquids from a container. AT: "you repeatedly committed your acts of prostitution" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you poured out your acts of prostitution

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of stopping the supply of food as if it were cutting off the food. AT: "stop your food supply" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: cut off your food

contextId.information: Here Yahweh speaks of the cities of Philistia as if they were the daughters of the Philistines. The cities represent the people who live there. AT: "the Philistine people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the daughters of the Philistines

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of Jerusalem's lust as if it were liquid and of committing actions repeatedly to gratify that lust as if it were pouring that liquid from a container. AT: "you repeatedly committed actions to gratify your lust" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you have poured your lust out

contextId.information: The Amorites and Hittites were both pagan people groups who lived in the land before the people of Israel conquered it. Yahweh speaks of Jerusalem's father and mother belonging to these people groups to express that she was born into idolatry. See how you translated these phrases in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:16:01|16:3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Your mother was a Hittite, and your father was an Amorite

contextId.information: Samaria and Sodom were both cities that Yahweh had judged for their idolatry and wickedness. Yahweh speaks of these cities being Jerusalem's sisters to express that she belonged to a family that practiced idolatry and wickedness. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Your older sister was Samaria ... your younger sister was the one living south of you, that is, Sodom

contextId.information: Here Yahweh speaks of the cities of Edom and Philistia as if they were the daughters of Edom and of the Philistines. The cities represent the people who live there. AT: "the Edomite people and to all the Philistine people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the daughters of Edom and to all the daughters of the Philistines

contextId.information: The kingdom being small and weak is spoken of as if it were lowly and being large and powerful as if it lifted itself up. AT: "so the kingdom might remain small and not become great" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so the kingdom might become lowly and not lift itself up

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of a person obeying his statutes as if the statutes were a path in which the person walks. AT: "he obeys my statutes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he walks in my statutes

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of obeying his statutes as if the person were walking along his statutes. AT: "obeys my statutes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: walks according to my statutes

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of a person being responsible for or guilty of iniquity as if the iniquity were an object that the person carries. AT: "Why is the son not responsible for the iniquity of his father?" or "Why is the son not guilty of the iniquity of his father?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Why does the son not bear the iniquity of his father?

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of a person's lifestyle or behavior as if it were a way on which the person walks. The idiom "to turn away" from something means to stop doing that thing. AT: "not in his ceasing to live the way that he lives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: not in his turning away from his way

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the person thinking about and understanding something as if the person were seeing it. AT: "he has considered" or "he has understood" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he has seen

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of "transgressions" causing people to rebel against him as if they were blocks over which the people stumble. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: turn away from all your transgressions so that they will not be stumbling blocks of iniquity against you

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the people determining to stop committing transgressions as if the transgressions were objects, such as clothing, that they removed and threw away. AT: "Get rid of all of the transgressions that you have committed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Throw away from off yourselves all of the transgressions that you have committed

contextId.information: The very dry land is spoken of as if it were thirsty. AT: "in a very dry land of drought" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in a land of drought and thirst

contextId.information: "It was a land where plenty of milk and honey flowed." Yahweh speaks of the land being good for animals and plants as if the milk and honey from those animals and plants were flowing through the land. AT: "It was land that was excellent for raising livestock and growing crops" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: It was flowing with milk and honey

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the people worshiping the detestable things as if they had placed those idols in front of their eyes. AT: "the detestable things that he worships" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the detestable things from before his eyes

contextId.information: A person who is not acceptable for God's purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Do not make yourselves unclean

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the people worshiping the detestable things as if they had placed those idols in front of their eyes. AT: "the detestable things that he worshiped" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the detestable things from before his eyes

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of obeying his statutes as if the statutes were a path along which a person walks. AT: "They did not obey my statutes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They did not walk in my statutes

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of expressing his fury by punishing them as if his fury were a liquid that he poured out on them. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:20:08|20:8]]. AT: "I would act against them in my fury" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I would pour out my fury upon them

contextId.information: "a land where plenty of milk and honey flowed." Yahweh speaks of the land being good for animals and plants as if the milk and honey from those animals and plants were flowing through the land. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:20:04|20:6]]. AT: "a land that was excellent for raising livestock and growing crops" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: a land flowing with milk and honey

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of obeying his statutes as if they were a path along which a person walks. AT: "did not obey my statutes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: did not walk in my statutes

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of a person obeying statutes as if the statutes were paths along with a person walks. AT: "Do not obey the statutes of your parents ... obey my statutes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Do not walk according to the statutes of your parents ... walk in my statutes

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of a person obeying his statutes as if the statutes were a path along which the person walks. AT: "They did not obey my statutes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They did not walk in my statutes

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of expressing his fury by punishing them as if his fury were a liquid that he poured out on them. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:20:08|20:8]]. AT: "to act against them in my fury" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to pour out my fury upon them

contextId.information: Here the "nations" refer to the people who live in those places. The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. AT: "in the thoughts of the people in other nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in the eyes of the nations

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of expressing his fury as if the fury were a liquid that he pours on on the people. This can be stated in active form. AT: "fury that I will pour out on you" or "I will express my fury towards you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: fury that will be poured out on you

contextId.information: This refers to the practice of a shepherd counting and inspecting his sheep as the sheep walked under his staff. Possible meanings are 1) Yahweh will count his people whom he gathers from the nations to ensure that they are all present. AT: "I will count you carefully as a shepherd counts his sheep" or 2) Yahweh will inspect each person as they pass under his staff in order to separate the faithful from the unfaithful. AT: "I will inspect you carefully as a shepherd inspects his sheep" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will cause you to pass under my rod

contextId.information: A person who is not acceptable for God's purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you made yourselves unclean

contextId.information: This speaks of Yahweh causing these people to die as if he actually killed them with his own sword. AT: "it will be as though I pull my sword from its sheath and strike" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my sword will go out from its sheath against

contextId.information: This speaks of people becoming fearful in their spirits as if their spirits were about to faint. AT: "Everyone will be fearful in their inner being" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Every spirit will grow faint

contextId.information: Here the sword of Yahweh represents men with swords that are to attack Jerusalem. Also, the word "slaughter" can be expressed as a verb. AT: "placed soldiers armed with swords at their gates, ready to slaughter the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: set the slaughter of the sword

contextId.information: The sword of Yahweh represents the men with swords that are to attack Jerusalem. This speaks of them being released to attack as if they were released to butcher the people in the same way that animals are butchered. AT: "released to slaughter the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: set free to butcher!

contextId.information: This refers to the sword of Yahweh which is a metaphor for the soldiers that Yahweh uses to kill a large number of people who have be disobedient to him. AT: "Swords! My soldiers have drawn their swords! They are sharpened for the slaughter" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: A sword, a sword is drawn! It is sharpened for the slaughter

contextId.information: This speaks of the city being a place where many people were killed as a place where blood is poured out in the streets. AT: "that sheds the blood of many people" or "that murders many people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that pours out blood in her midst

contextId.information: A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: unclean

contextId.information: This speaks of murdering people as pouring out blood. AT: "because you murdered innocent people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: by the blood that you have poured out

contextId.information: A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: unclean

contextId.information: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. AT: "and cause the people of every land to consider you a derision" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in the sight of every land

contextId.information: This speaks of murdering people as pouring out blood. AT: "to murder people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to pour out blood

contextId.information: A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: uncleanness

contextId.information: Here the "nations" refer to the people who live in those places. The "eyes" represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. AT: "So the nations will consider you unclean" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: So you will become unclean in the eyes of the nations

contextId.information: Dross is the impurities that are left over after silver or gold has been purified in a furnace. Here Yahweh speaks of the people being worthless to him as if the were dross. AT: "has become as worthless to me as dross" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: has become dross to me

contextId.information: A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: not been cleansed

contextId.information: This speaks of the prophets trying to hide the these sins as if they were something that they could paint over with whitewash. AT: "It is like her prophets have painted over their sins with whitewash" or "Their prophets try to hide these evil things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Her prophets have painted them over with whitewash

contextId.information: "Oholah represents Samaria, and Oholibah represents Jerusalem." In this metaphor Samaria is spoken of as if it were Oholah and Jerusalem is spoken of as if it were Oholibah. This speaks of how these cities were unfaithful to Yahweh as if they were unfaithful wives. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Their names mean this: Oholah means Samaria, and Oholibah means Jerusalem

contextId.information: A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: unclean

contextId.information: A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: unclean

contextId.information: Here Yahweh speaks causing the armies to attack them because he is angry with them as if his anger where something that he was placing upon them. AT: Because I am very jealous for you, I will cause them to act furiously towards you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For I will set my jealous anger on you, and they will deal with you in fury

contextId.information: Oholibah's sister Oholah represents Samaria. Samaria is called by it's name but still referred to as a sister. The cup is a symbol for the punishment that she received. AT: "for this is the same cup of punishment that you sister drank, who represents Samaria"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the cup of your sister Samaria

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of Oholibah rejecting him as if he were an object that he had thrown behind her back and forgotten. AT: "and rejected me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and thrown me away behind your back

contextId.information: A person or thing God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if it were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: unclean

contextId.information: Yahweh continues to compare Jerusalem to a cooking pot. AT: "it is like a cooking pot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a cooking pot

contextId.information: Here the word "she" refers to the cooking pot. This is the cooking pot that is metaphorical for Jerusalem. AT: "Jerusalem has become tired" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: She has become weary

contextId.information: Here wasting away and dying is spoken of as melting. AT: "you will become very thin and slowly die" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you will melt away

contextId.information: Here the word "sign" refers to something that communicates a special warning to those who see it. Yahweh speaks of Ezekiel and his actions as being this warning. See how you translated this metaphor in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:12:04|12:6]]. AT: "So Ezekiel will be a warning for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: So Ezekiel will be a sign for you

contextId.information: "which bring them joy and pride, which they look at and delight in" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: which is their joy, their pride, and what they see and desire

contextId.information: Here the word "sign" refers to something that communicates a special warning to those who see it. Yahweh speaks of Ezekiel and his actions as being this warning. See how you translated this metaphor in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:12:04|12:6]]. AT: "You will be a warning for them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You will be a sign for them

contextId.information: This speaks of the enemy army conquering the land of Ammon and taking possession of the land and everything in it as if the enemy were taking the people of Ammon as their possession. It is not implied here that the enemy took the people of Ammon as slaves. AT: "I will cause an army from a land that is east of you to come and conquer you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am giving you to a people in the east as their possession

contextId.information: "I will hit you with my powerful hand." Here Yahweh speaks of punishing the people as if he were literally hitting them with his hand. AT: "I will punish you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will strike you with my hand

contextId.information: Here Yahweh speaks of allowing the armies from the east to conquer Ammon as if Ammon were a possession that he were giving them. AT: "I will allow the armies to conquer them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will give them up as a possession

contextId.information: The people of Tyre use these words to refer to Jerusalem as if it were a city gate through which traders from the surrounding nations pass. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Armies have broken down the gates of the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: The gates of the people are broken

contextId.information: This metaphor describes the results after Yahweh completely destroys Tyre. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:26:03|26:4]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will make you a bare rock

contextId.information: This metaphor represents the princes trembling enough to seem like it was their clothing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They will clothe themselves with trembling

contextId.information: This represents being restored to the city's former existence. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: stand in the land of the living

contextId.information: "I will sit on the throne of the gods." Here sitting in the seat of the gods represents claiming to be in the same exalted position as if he were one of the gods. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will sit in the seat of the gods

contextId.information: Here being in the hand of someone represents being under their control. AT: "under the control of" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in the hand of

contextId.information: "the stones of fire." Possible meanings are 1) a metaphor for the colorful and bright stones mentioned in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:28:11|28:13]] or 2) other fiery stones on the "holy mountain of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the fiery stones

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the king of Tyre as if he was a container that was filled up with violence. The abstract noun "violence" can be translated using the adjective "violent." AT: "you were fully violent" or "you were completely violent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: you were filled with violence

contextId.information: "the stones of fire." Possible meanings are 1) a metaphor for the colorful and bright stones mentioned in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:28:11|28:13]] or 2) other fiery stones on the "holy mountain of God." Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:28:14|28:14]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the fiery stones

contextId.information: Here "blood" refers to the blood of the people of Sidon and represents those whom their enemies would kill. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: blood in your streets

contextId.information: Here the briars and thorns represent what would cause suffering and pain. AT: "people anywhere around the house of Israel who wound them like briars, hurt them like thorns, and despise them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: pricking briars and painful thorns for the house of Israel from all those around her who despise her people

contextId.information: God speaks of Israel relying on Egypt as if they were taking hold of a reed stalk in order to use it as a crutch. AT: "When they relied on you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: When they took hold of you in their hand

contextId.information: Here "cut off man and beast" is a metaphor for destroying the people and animals. God would do this by causing the enemy army to do it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will cut off both man and beast from you

contextId.information: The phrase "fortunes of Egypt" is a metaphor for the people of Egypt who had been taken away to other countries. AT: "I will bring back the people of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will restore the fortunes of Egypt

contextId.information: Here "lowly" represents unimportant. AT: "an unimportant kingdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a lowly kingdom

contextId.information: Here "lowliest" represents least important. AT: "the least important of the kingdoms" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the lowliest of the kingdoms

contextId.information: "I will make them small." Here "diminish them" represents making Egypt weak or unimportant. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will diminish them

contextId.information: Here "payment" represents the valuable things that Nebuchadnezzar's army would steal from Tyre as a reward for defeating it. God speaks of these things as if they were what God would pay them for working for him. AT: "he and his army did not get any valuable things from Tyre as reward" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he and his army received no payment from Tyre

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of causing the army of Babylon to defeat Egypt as if God were giving Egypt to Nebuchadnezzar. AT: "I will cause the army of Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, to defeat Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am giving the land of Egypt to Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon

contextId.information: Being "among" the ruined cities represents being ruined like the ruined cities of other countries. AT: "their cities will ruined like the cities of other countries" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: their cities will be among all the ruined cities

contextId.information: Yahweh will give the Babylonians control over Egypt just as a person who sells something gives the one who buys it control over that thing. AT: "I will give control of the land to wicked men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will sell the land into the hand of wicked men

contextId.information: Here "put terror on the land" represents causing the people of the land to be very afraid. AT: "I will make the people of Egypt very afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will put terror on the land of Egypt

contextId.information: Here "pour out my fury" represents punishing the people because of his great anger. AT: "For I will act in great anger against Pelusium" or "Because I am so angry, I will punish Pelusium severely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For I will pour out my fury on Pelusium

contextId.information: Here "cut off" represents killing the people. AT: "kill the very large number of people in Thebes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: cut off the multitude of Thebes

contextId.information: The word "yoke" here refers to Egypt's power to oppress people. AT: "when I stop Egypt from oppressing people" or "when I end Egypt's power to cruelly control other nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: when I break the yoke of Egypt there

contextId.information: This represents Egypt no longer being proud of their strength. The reason that they will not be proud is that they will no longer be strong. AT: "Egypt will no longer be proud about being strong" or "Egypt will no longer have the strength that they were so proud of" (See:[[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: the pride of her strength will be finished

contextId.information: It was common to speak of a person's life as if it were a lamp that could be put out. AT: "When I destroy you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: when I extinguish you

contextId.information: The nation of Egypt, symbolized by its king, is spoken of as if it were a building that was collapsing. AT: "when nations hear about the way I destroyed you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: when I bring about your collapse among the nations

contextId.information: The idea of falling down ("downfall") represents dying. AT: "when I destroy you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: on the day of your downfall

contextId.information: The land of Assyria is represented as a woman. AT: "The people of Assyria and all its army are there in Sheol" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Assyria is there with all her assembly

contextId.information: Shame is spoken of as if it were an object that one could carry where he goes. AT: "who feel ashamed" or "who are now disgraced" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who carry their own shame

contextId.information: The warriors' iniquities cover their bodies, although one would expect that their shields would cover them in death. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: their iniquities over their bones

contextId.information: The time during which these warriors were living is spoken of as if it were a place. AT: "while they were alive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in the land of the living

contextId.information: Acting or behaving in a certain way is spoken of as if it were walking. AT: "lives according to the laws that give life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: walks in the statutes that give life

contextId.information: Behaviors or actions is spoken of as if they were a way or road on which a person travels. AT: "What the Lord does ... the things you do that are not fair" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The way of the Lord ... your ways that are not fair

contextId.information: No longer doing something is spoken of as if it were physically turning away from something. AT: "stops doing what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: turns away from his righteousness

contextId.information: No longer doing something is spoken of as if it were physically turning away from something. AT: "stops doing wicked things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: turns away from his wickedness

contextId.information: Yahweh giving the land to Abraham is spoken of as if Abraham inherited the land. AT: "Yahweh gave him the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he inherited the land

contextId.information: The leaders of Israel are spoken as if they were shepherds. They were supposed to take care of their people like shepherds take care of their flock. AT: "the leaders of Israel who are like shepherds" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the shepherds of Israel

contextId.information: This continues speaking of the leaders of Israel as if they were bad shepherds that kill the best animals in their flock for food and clothing. AT: "You are like shepherds who eat the fatty portions ... dress in wool" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You eat the fatty portions ... dress in wool

contextId.information: Yahweh bringing his people back from exile to their land so that he can care for them and keep them safe is spoken of as if he were their shepherd who puts his flock in a place where there is plenty of land, food, and water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will put them in pastures ... every settlement in the land

contextId.information: The descendant of David being the king over the people of Israel is spoken of as if he would be their shepherd. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will shepherd them

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "cut off" is a metaphor that means to destroy. AT: "I will destroy anyone who enters it or leaves it" (UDB) or 2) "cut off" is a metaphor that means to stop someone from doing something. AT: "I will make it so that people do not travel back and forth through it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: when I cut off from it anyone who passes through and returns again

contextId.information: This speaks of the land that Yahweh gave to the Israelites as if they inherited the land. AT: "As you rejoiced when I made the land of the Israelites desolate" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: As you rejoiced over the inheritance of the people of Israel because of its desolation

contextId.information: This speaks of Yahweh's fury as if it were a fire. Yahweh loves Israel very much, so he becomes jealous and angry when other nations mock it. AT: "because of my intense jealousy" or "because of my very strong anger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in the fire of my fury

contextId.information: Not enough food growing in Israel so that people die is spoken of as if the mountains of Israel were devouring the people. AT: "You cause many people to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You devour people

contextId.information: Not enough food growing in Israel so that people die is spoken of as if the mountains of Israel were consuming the people. AT: "you will no longer cause the people to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you will not consume people any longer

contextId.information: Yahweh punishing people because he is angry is spoken of as if his fury were a liquid that he poured out. AT: "I did things to them that showed how angry I was" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I poured out my fury against them

contextId.information: The people worshiping idols is spoken of as if the idols made the land physically dirty. AT: "and because they defiled the land with their idols" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and for their pollution of it by their idols

contextId.information: Yahweh forgiving the people and causing them to no longer sin is spoken of as if he would cleanse them with water. The phrase "you will be purified" can be stated in active form. AT: "I will purify you as if I were sprinkling you with pure water, and I will cause you to stop worshiping idols" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: I will sprinkle pure water on you so you will be purified from all of your impurities, and I will purify you from all of your idols

contextId.information: Yahweh causing the people to no longer be stubborn but to love and serve Yahweh is spoken of as if he will take away their old heart and give them a new heart and spirit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will give you a new heart and a new spirit in your innermost parts, and I will take away the heart of stone from your flesh. For I will give you a heart of flesh

contextId.information: This speaks of people being stubborn as if their hearts were made of stone. See how you translated "stone heart" in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:11:19|11:19]]. AT: "the heart that is as hard as stone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the heart of stone

contextId.information: People being willing to serve Yahweh is spoken of as if their hearts were soft like flesh. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:11:19|11:19]]. AT: "a heart that is soft like flesh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a heart of flesh

contextId.information: Something that is unacceptable to Yahweh is spoken of as if it were physically unclean. AT: "For I will save you from everything that made me reject you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For I will save you from all of your uncleanness

contextId.information: Yahweh causing a famine in the land is spoken of as if he put famine on the people. AT: "I will no longer there to be a famine" or "I will no longer cause there to be no food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will no longer put famine upon you

contextId.information: Yahweh causing the people to multiply greatly and quickly is spoken of as if they were a flock of sheep. Sheep multiply very quickly. AT: "to make them multiply like a flock of sheep" or "to make the people multiply quickly like sheep" ([[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to increase them like a flock of people

contextId.information: This speaks of the people of Israel as if they were a flock of sheep. This can be stated in active form. AT: "so will be the great number of people who will be living in the cities that are now ruined but the people will rebuild" ([[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: so will be the ruined cities be filled with flocks of people

contextId.information: The people being destroyed and removed from their land is spoken of as if they had been cut off like a person would cut off a branch or piece of cloth. AT: "Our nation is destroyed" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: We have been cut off

contextId.information: Yahweh restoring the people and bringing them back to their land is spoken of as if he will bring them back to life again. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will open your graves and lift you out from them

contextId.information: This speaks of acting or behaving in a certain way as if it were a person walking. AT: "will live as I have commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will walk according to my decrees

contextId.information: Here "hooks in your jaw" represents God's control over Gog. People put hooks in the mouths of animals so that they could lead the animals wherever they wanted. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: set hooks in your jaw

contextId.information: The intensity if Yahweh's anger is spoken of as if it was a hot as a fire. AT: "because my anger was intense" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in the fire of my anger

contextId.information: God will lead Gog as if Gog was an animal. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will turn you and lead you on

contextId.information: Knocking Gog's bow and arrows out of his hands represents destroying his military power. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will knock your bow out of your left hand and make the arrows fall from your right hand.

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of his glory as if he will place it in the middle of the nations where they can see it. AT: "I will make the nations see my glory" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will set my glory among the nations

contextId.information: The idols that the people's kings worshiped are spoken of as if they are corpses because the idols are not alive. AT: "the lifeless idols that their kings worshiped" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the corpses of their kings

contextId.information: The idols that the people's kings worshiped are spoken of as if they are corpses because the idols are not alive. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:43:06|43:7]]. AT: "the lifeless idols that their kings worshiped" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the corpses of their kings
